questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine pelvic examination. She feels well. Menses occur at 30-day intervals and last 7 days. Her last menstrual period was 6 days ago. Her last Pap smear was 13 months ago and there is no history of abnormal findings. She is sexually active with three male partners and uses condoms consistently. She has never been tested for sexually transmitted infections. Her 54-year-old mother has breast cancer. She did not receive a human papillomavirus vaccine. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis testing, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

As part of the routine immunization schedule, the CDC states that two doses of the nine-valent human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine should be administered six to twelve months apart to all individuals aged 9–14 years. For all unvaccinated female individuals aged 15–26 years, the CDC recommends vaccination with three doses of the nine-valent HPV vaccine at 0, 2, and 6 months. The HPV vaccine is approved by the FDA for individuals up to the age of 45 years, but it is not routinely recommended by the CDC for individuals aged > 26 years.

Condoms lower the risk of, but do not protect against, HPV infection because HPV can still be transmitted via genital skin-to-skin contact or oral sex.

B) INCORRECT:

For women aged between 21 and 29 years, the USPSTF recommends a Pap smear every three years. Since this patient had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago, another Pap smear is not required for nearly another two years.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common indication for a pregnancy test is recent-onset secondary amenorrhea in a patient of childbearing age. Because her last menstrual period was six days ago, this patient does not have amenorrhea. If this 24-year-old woman had acute lower abdominal pain, a pregnancy test would be indicated to rule out an ectopic pregnancy. However, there is currently no indication for performing a pregnancy test in this asymptomatic patient presenting for a routine pelvic examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Cotesting refers to simultaneous Pap smear and HPV testing. It is the USPSTF's recommended cervical cancer screening of choice for women aged between 30 and 65 years every five years. In this 24-year-old patient, the USPSTF instead recommends a Pap smear every three years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend that women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.

E) INCORRECT:

HPV testing and a simultaneous Pap smear, known as cotesting, is recommended by the USPSTF for cervical cancer screening for patients aged 30–65 years every five years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing alone (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.
questions.hint: This patient's history and age determine the most appropriate recommendation at this time.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nulliparous woman with polycystic ovary syndrome comes to the physician for a pelvic examination and cervical cancer screening. Last year she had a progestin-releasing intrauterine device placed. Menarche occurred at the age of 10 years. She became sexually active at the age of 14 years. Her mother had breast cancer at the age of 51 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Examination shows mild facial acne. HPV testing is positive. Cytology shows high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. Colposcopy with biopsy shows cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade II. Which of the following is this patient's strongest predisposing factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

HPV serotypes 16 and 18 are oncogenic viruses that increase the risk of CIN by producing the oncogenic proteins E6 and E7. The strongest predisposing factors for HPV infection are the early onset of sexual activity and multiple sexual partners. Women who engage in sexual activity before the age of 18 years are at twice the risk of cervical cancer compared to women who are 21 years or older when they first have intercourse. The risk of cervical cancer in women who have had ≥ 6 sexual partners is increased threefold compared with one partner. Other HPV-related risk factors include high-risk sexual behavior, a history of STIs, a history of immunosuppression, and intrauterine exposure to diethylstilbestrol. Higher rates of cervical cancer have also been observed in women of low socioeconomic status and smokers (for squamous cell cancer types only).
Image Description:

Almost all cases of cervical cancer are caused by an infection of the transformation zone (rectangular box) with high-risk types of human papillomavirus (HPV).

HPVs infect the stem cells of the basal cell epithelium. Cell proliferation and migration of virus-infected daughter cells into the suprabasal cell layer allow the infection to spread. At the beginning of the process, the DNA of the virus is episomal. As the disease progresses, the DNA is integrated into the cervical epithelium's DNA. A noninvasive precursor lesion, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), may develop from an HPV infection over months to years, which may ultimately progress to invasive carcinoma.

In most cases, complete recovery will occur during the early stages of an HPV infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive use > 5 years is associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer, whereas intrauterine device use actually decreases the risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Obesity increases the risk of endometrial cancer, not cervical cancer. This is due to increased aromatase activity in the abundant adipose tissue, which leads to increased levels of circulating estrogens.

D) INCORRECT:

Nulliparity increases the risk of developing endometrial cancer, not cervical cancer because nulliparous women are not exposed to the significant increase in progesterone that occurs during pregnancy. In contrast, both high parity and early age of first birth (< 20 years old), increase the risk for cervical cancer, although these factors may be mediated by increased exposure to HPV.

E) INCORRECT:

Early menarche is not a known risk factor for developing cervical cancer, but it is associated with an increased incidence of endometrial cancer due to the increased lifetime exposure to estrogen (similarly to late menopause).

F) INCORRECT:

While a family history of gynecological cancers does increase this patient's risk of developing cervical cancer, it is not the strongest predisposing factor.

G) INCORRECT:

While PCOS is likely the cause of this woman's acne, it is not an established risk factor for the development of cervical cancer. It is, however, associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer due to the excess circulating estrogen, a direct result of decreased production of sex hormone-binding globulin.
questions.hint: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) is strongly associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, especially the high-risk HPV types 16 and 18.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for a scheduled colposcopy. Two weeks ago, she had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy shows an area of white discoloration of the cervix with application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area shows carcinoma-in-situ. Activation of which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phosphoprotein p24, which is a component of the HIV virus, is not related to HPV infection or the pathogenesis of cervical dysplasia as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutations of the JAK-2 gene are seen in polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and other chronic myeloproliferative disorders. Although these mutations cause deregulation of cell growth and division, they are not associated with the cervical dysplasia seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

E2F transcription factors that promote G1 to the S phase transition are normally inhibited by the retinoblastoma protein (pRb). High-risk types of HPV induce production of the oncoprotein E7, which binds and inactivates pRb, thereby increasing G1 to S phase transition and cell proliferation. High-risk HPV also induces the production of the oncoprotein E6, which binds and inactivates the tumor suppressor protein p53.

D) INCORRECT:

The p53 protein is a key tumor suppressor. Therefore, activation of the p53 protein would inhibit rather than promote tumor growth. Oncogenic HPV DNA induces the expression of the E6 protein, which binds and inactivates p53.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK) are responsible for progression of the cell cycle. Therefore, activation of CDK inhibitors would arrest the cell cycle and prevent rather than promote tumor growth. Oncogenic HPV DNA induces the expression of E7 protein, which binds and inactivates the CDK inhibitors p21 and p27.
questions.hint: High-risk human papillomavirus subtypes, e.g., HPV 16 and HPV 18, are responsible for the majority of cervical cancers. These pathogens facilitate the transcription of proteins that alter tumor suppression upon successful infection of cervical cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of vaginal bleeding after intercourse. Menarche occurred at the age of 13 years and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Gynecologic examination shows an irregular lesion at the cervical os. Histological evaluation of a cervical biopsy specimen obtained on colposcopy confirms a diagnosis of in-situ cervical cancer. This cancer is most likely derived from which of the following types of cells?

choices.text: Simple columnar epithelium with tubular glands

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Simple columnar epithelium with tubular glands appears in the uterus during the proliferative phase as well as in the endocervix up to the transformation zone. This type of epithelium can develop into adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) of the cervix, a precursor to cervical adenocarcinoma, and requires proper management in order to prevent invasive disease. However, AIS is less common (∼ 20% of cases) than other types of cervical cancer, making a different option more likely.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of uterine tissue (H&E stain; 100x magnification)

Tissue layers (from bottom left to top right and from inside out):
– Myometrium (light purple)
– Endometrium (dark purple) with endometrial glands (white)

During the beginning of the proliferative phase, the endometrial glands are still relatively straight, unlike the cork-screw shape they adopt during the late proliferative and the luteal phase.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

Ciliated simple columnar epithelium lines the fallopian tubes and enables the movement towards the tubal ampulla and uterus. In extremely rare cases, tubal adenocarcinomas may metastasize to the cervix. However, ciliated simple columnar epithelium is not present in the cervix and metastasis from the fallopian tubes would not manifest as an in-situ cervical cancer, but involve the deep stroma as well.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of cross section of fallopian tube (H&E stain, 25x magnification)

Tissue layers (from the inside out):

Lumen (white) and highly folded mucosa (dark purple)
Muscularis (purple)
Serosa (light purple)
Branches of the ovarian and uterine artery (purple epithelium with red and white lumen; right)

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) CORRECT:

Cervical cancer most frequently evolves from non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium (∼ 80% of cervical cancers are squamous cell carcinoma). The transformation zone, or squamocolumnar junction, between the ectocervix (squamous epithelium) and endocervix (columnar epithelium) is especially prone to metaplasia. When the epithelium is infected with HPV, dysplastic epithelium can develop and eventually progress to in-situ cervical carcinoma, which is characterized by severely dysplastic, undifferentiated cells present at the basal epithelial layer.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of uterine tissue (H&E Stain)

The uterine cervix is divided into the endocervix (covered with columnar epithelium (yellow overlay), consisting of one layer of mucin-secreting cells) and the ectocervix (covered with non-keratinizing, stratified squamous epithelium (red overlay)). Underneath both types of epithelium, a layer of connective tissue can be found. In between, a transitional area, known as the squamocolumnar junction (black dashed line), is visible. As a result of the constant remodeling process due to uterine growth, cervical enlargement and hormonal status, it is where most precancerous lesions of the cervix are located.

No pathologies are noted.

D) INCORRECT:

Simple cuboidal cells form the germinal epithelium that covers the ovaries. Female germinal epithelium was previously thought to give rise to serous cystadenocarcinoma, the most common and aggressive type of ovarian cancer, but recent research has shown that this type of cancer is most likely derived from fallopian tube epithelium. Ovarian cancers can metastasize to the cervix. However, this is extremely rare and would not manifest as an in-situ cervical cancer, but involve the deep stroma as well.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of the ovary (H&E stain, ca. 450x magnification)

The ovary is completely surrounded by cubic to columnar epithelium (peritoneal epithelium, black arrow).
Underneath is the tunica albuginea (black line), a thin layer of connective tissue.
Beneath is the cortex ovari, which consists of spinocellular connective tissue, in which the numerous ovarian follicles in their different stages of development are embedded. Most of them are primordial follicles (some overlayed in green) in diktyotän, a dormant stage. In the two marked primordial follicles, condensed chromosomes are seen as basophile “lumps”, which is typical for this state.
Ther is a primary follicle (dashed outline) on the left, clearly distinguishable by the single layer of cubic epithelial cells.
On the lower edge are luteinized theca cells (white arrows), which are presumably part of a corpus luteum, which is not completely on the picture.

E) INCORRECT:

Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium covers the skin of the entire body, including the vulva, providing protection against mechanical force, pathogens, and desiccation. This type of epithelium is susceptible to cancerous mutation (especially following HPV infection) with potential metastasis to the cervix. However, metastasis to the cervix is extremely rare and would involve the deep stroma, instead of just the epithelium, as seen with in-situ carcinoma.
questions.hint: By definition, in-situ cancers of the cervix are premalignant, confined to the site of their formation, and have not spread to any surrounding tissues or organs. The most common site of formation for cervical cancer is the transformation zone.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination and cervical cancer screening. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago and showed no abnormalities. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 32 years. She takes no medications apart from a multivitamin supplement. Physical examination shows no breast masses. The external genitalia, vagina, and cervix appear normal. The uterus and adnexa are normal to palpation. HPV testing is positive. Cytology shows squamous cells with moderate to severe dysplasia and several koilocytes. Colposcopy with biopsy shows moderate epithelial dysplasia of half of the basal epithelium with an intact basement membrane. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic polycythemia is a paraneoplastic syndrome caused by the autonomous production of EPO by tumors. Cervical cancer is not commonly associated with paraneoplastic polycythemia. Cancers more commonly associated with this condition include renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, and cerebellar hemangioma.

B) INCORRECT:

Superior vena cava syndrome (SVC syndrome) is caused by the obstruction of blood flow in the SVC. The most common cause of SVC syndrome is malignancy, with lung cancer and non-Hodgkin lymphoma accounting for almost all the cases. Although the lung is a common site of distant metastasis in cervical cancer, it is not usually associated with SVC syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Leptomeningeal metastases are caused by the metastatic infiltration of the meninges by cancer cells from a primary tumor. Cervical cancer is not commonly associated with leptomeningeal metastasis. The malignant tumors that most commonly metastasize to the leptomeninges are breast cancer, lung cancer, and melanoma.

D) CORRECT:

Postrenal azotemia is caused by obstruction of the urinary tract. Although the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer in the US have been decreasing as a result of Pap smear screening, if it is not detected or left untreated, it can invade adjacent structures, one of which is the bladder wall. The progressive invasion of the bladder wall can lead to the obstruction of the ureters, which causes hydronephrosis. Cervical cancer can also cause hydronephrosis by direct obstruction of the ureters (proximal to the bladder). Hydronephrosis increases the retrograde hydrostatic pressure within tubules. Consequently, bilateral hydronephrosis can lead to a decline in the glomerular filtration rate, ultimately resulting in acute renal failure. Other local complications of invasive cervical cancer include fistula formation and lower extremity edema caused by the compression of veins or lymphatics in the lower pelvis.

E) INCORRECT:

Pericardial effusion is associated with a variety of underlying disorders, one of which is malignancy. Although almost any malignancy can spread to the pericardium, cervical cancer is not commonly associated with pericardial metastasis. The malignant tumors that most commonly metastasize to the pericardium are Hodgkin lymphoma, lung cancer, and breast cancer.
questions.hint: This patient's moderate epithelial dysplasia is consistent with CIN II, which can progress to invasive cervical cancer if left untreated. Anterior invasion of a cervical carcinoma can affect the neighboring structures.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with known HIV infection comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of postcoital spotting and irregular vaginal bleeding. Prior to the onset of her symptoms, menses occurred at regular 28-day intervals. She is sexually active with multiple sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include a combined antiretroviral treatment regimen and an oral contraceptive. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen obtained from the cervix is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix
Squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the cervix
Adenocarcinoma in situ of the cervix

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of postcoital spotting, irregular vaginal bleeding, HIV infection, and unprotected sex with multiple partners may indicate bacterial cervicitis, which is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhea. The neutrophils seen on biopsy may further suggest an acute bacterial infection. However, the atypical columnar epithelial cells seen here indicate a malignant process.

B) CORRECT:

The photomicrograph shows atypical columnar epithelial cells with elongated nuclei and vacuolated cytoplasm. These cells have infiltrated beyond the basement membrane and are arranged in gland-like formations within the subepithelial stroma. These findings indicate an invasive cervical adenocarcinoma, which accounts for approx. 20% of all cervical cancer cases. Smoking is only a risk factor for cervical squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), the most common form of cervical cancer, but immunodeficiency (especially HIV infection), multiple sex partners, and HPV infection are risk factors for both cervical adenocarcinoma and cervical SCC.

C) INCORRECT:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) constitutes 80% of all cervical carcinomas. However, a biopsy would show nests, cords, or sheets of well-differentiated eosinophilic cells and keratin pearls, or round undifferentiated hyperchromatic cells. Atypical columnar cells with vacuolated cytoplasm, as seen here, would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cervical tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Cancer cells with nuclear atypia are growing within the subepithelial stroma (purple area). Tumor necrosis is present throughout the cancerous mass, seen here as an amorphous eosinophilic accumulation of cell debris. The abundance of neutrophils accompanying the invasive component is a sign of active inflammation secondary to malignant neoplasia.

This is the typical appearance of squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has a malignancy of the cervix, but the biopsy findings show that the basement membrane has been breached because the cancerous cells are situated within the subepithelial stroma. Therefore, this malignancy is not in situ.
Image Description:

LSIL: low-grade squamous intraepithelial neoplasia
HSIL: high-grade squamous intraepithelial neoplasia
CIN: cervical intraepithelial neoplasia

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a malignancy of the cervix but the biopsy findings show that the basement membrane has been breached because the cancerous cells are situated within the subepithelial stroma. Therefore, this malignancy is not in situ.
questions.hint: The biopsy findings in this patient with postcoital spotting and irregular vaginal bleeding indicate a cervical malignancy. This patient has the less common type of cervical malignancy.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman (gravida 3, para 3) undergoes a colposcopic evaluation for a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion that was detected on a routine Pap test. Cervical biopsy results from that evaluation confirm the presence of a microinvasive squamous-cell carcinoma of the cervix. Endocervical canal sampling is negative.
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Concurrent chemoradiation therapy is the primary treatment of choice for disease stages with a high risk of recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy can be an option for medically inoperable patients and for patients who refuse surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapy, without concurrent radiation therapy, is reserved mainly for patients with recurrent or metastatic disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Pelvic lymph-node dissection is recommended for patients with lymphovascular invasion on biopsy.

E) CORRECT:

Very early stages of cervical cancer are often asymptomatic, and squamous-cell carcinomas comprise about 80% of all cases. Treatment options depend on careful clinical evaluation and staging. Cervical cold-knife conization, also known as cone biopsy, is necessary to evaluate the depth and stage of the disease.

If the cone biopsy shows negative margins and the patient wishes to preserve her fertility, observation alone is acceptable. Positive margins warrant either repeat cone biopsy or radical trachelectomy (i.e., surgical removal of the cervix).

Key learning point: The correct initial management for a microinvasive squamous-cell carcinoma biopsy of the cervix is cervical cold-knife conization.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old nulliparous woman with HIV presents for a follow-up appointment. She has been on combination antiretroviral therapy since her HIV diagnosis one year ago, and her HIV viral load is undetectable. She has not had a Pap test since her early 20s.
During the past 3 months, she has been experiencing progressively worsening vaginal bleeding between menstrual periods and says the bleeding is particularly worse after sexual intercourse.
Which one of the following findings is most likely to be noted on pelvic examination?

choices.text: A cluster of small papules with a cauliflower appearance on the vaginal wall and vulva
An ulcerated lesion arising from the transformation zone of the cervix
A small cyst along the outer edge of the cervix

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bleeding from the cervical os and the presence of an adnexal mass are characteristics of endometrial cancer and ovarian cancer, respectively. The risk for these cancers may be only slightly increased in people with HIV. Endometrial and ovarian cancers are not typically associated with postcoital bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Cauliflower-like growths on the vaginal wall and vulva are most likely genital warts. Although these are common in the setting of HIV infection, they are often asymptomatic and are infrequently associated with postcoital bleeding.

C) CORRECT:

Irregular bleeding that is exacerbated by sexual intercourse is a typical presentation of cervical cancer. Pelvic examination in patients with cervical cancer typically reveals a lesion at the transformation zone of the cervix, where the cancer is most likely to originate.

The risk for cervical cancer is much higher in people with HIV than in the general population, even in patients taking antiretroviral therapy. One reason may be that people with HIV are more likely to acquire human papillomavirus infection and less likely to clear it. Fortunately, screening for cervical cancer with regular Pap smears is highly effective in those with HIV, just as it is in those without HIV. Thus, annual Pap smears are recommended in this population. Consequently, cervical cancer is a very rare cause of HIV-related morbidity and mortality, except in patients who are not screened according to guidelines.

Key learning point: The risk for cervical cancer is much higher in people with HIV than in the general population, even in patients taking antiretroviral therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Small cysts along the outer edge of the cervix are most likely Nabothian cysts, which are benign. They rarely cause excess vaginal bleeding and are not associated with HIV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Bleeding from the cervical os and the presence of an adnexal mass are characteristics of endometrial cancer and ovarian cancer, respectively. The risk for these cancers may be only slightly increased in people with HIV. Endometrial and ovarian cancers are not typically associated with postcoital bleeding.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports 6 months of postcoital bleeding. She is a current smoker with a 30-pack-year history. Her last Pap test, performed 10 years ago, showed a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Pelvic examination today reveals a firm, 2-cm, friable nodule on the cervix.
Which one of the following procedures is the most appropriate next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most appropriate initial diagnostic step in a woman with a visible cervical lesion is a cervical biopsy to evaluate for invasive carcinoma.

Infection with high-risk strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV) can lead to abnormal Pap test results or cervical dysplasia. Additional risk factors for persistent HPV infection and progression of dysplasia include cigarette smoking and an immunocompromised state. If left untreated, cervical dysplasia can progress to invasive carcinoma of the cervix, which can be prevented through early detection of premalignant cells of the cervix. This is the rationale for screening asymptomatic women using routine Pap tests with HPV testing.

In this case, the patient has a visible abnormality on the cervix, and the best test is therefore referral for colposcopy with cervical biopsy. Although obtaining a Pap test at the time of the pelvic examination would be reasonable, it would not be sufficient to fully evaluate the lesion, and a biopsy is therefore still required.

Key learning point: Diagnosis of cervical cancer is confirmed by biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

An endometrial biopsy is a diagnostic test for suspected endometrial cancer and is not the best test in this case, where the presentation is suspicious for cervical cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Staging laparoscopy is not indicated in this case, given that a cancer diagnosis has not yet been confirmed.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical conization and loop electrosurgical excision are used to treat premalignant lesions of the cervix but are not appropriate for the initial evaluation of a mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Cervical conization and loop electrosurgical excision are used to treat premalignant lesions of the cervix but are not appropriate for the initial evaluation of a mass.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports 6 months of postcoital bleeding. She is a current smoker with a 30-pack-year history. Her last Pap test, performed 10 years ago, showed a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Pelvic examination today reveals a firm, 2-cm, friable nodule on the cervix. Which one of the following procedures is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

A) CORRECT:

In this case, the patient has a visible abnormality on the cervix, and the best test is therefore referral for colposcopy with cervical biopsy. Although obtaining a Pap test at the time of the pelvic examination would be reasonable, it would not be sufficient to fully evaluate the lesion, and a biopsy is therefore still required.

B) INCORRECT:

An endometrial biopsy is a diagnostic test for suspected endometrial cancer and is not the best test in this case, where the presentation is suspicious for cervical cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Staging laparoscopy is not indicated in this case, given that a cancer diagnosis has not yet been confirmed.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical conization and loop electrosurgical excision are used to treat premalignant lesions of the cervix but are not appropriate for the initial evaluation of a mass.

E) INCORRECT:

Cervical conization and loop electrosurgical excision are used to treat premalignant lesions of the cervix but are not appropriate for the initial evaluation of a mass.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman with HIV presents for a follow-up appointment. She has been on combination antiretroviral therapy since her HIV diagnosis one year ago, and her HIV viral load is undetectable. She has not had a Pap test since her early 20s. During the past 3 months, she has been experiencing progressively worsening vaginal bleeding between menstrual periods and says the bleeding is particularly worse after sexual intercourse. Which one of the following findings is most likely to be noted on pelvic examination?

choices.text: A cluster of small papules with a cauliflower appearance on the vaginal wall and vulva
An ulcerated lesion arising from the transformation zone of the cervix
A small cyst along the outer edge of the cervix

A) INCORRECT:

Bleeding from the cervical os and the presence of an adnexal mass are characteristics of endometrial cancer and ovarian cancer, respectively. The risk for these cancers may be only slightly increased in people with HIV. Endometrial and ovarian cancers are not typically associated with postcoital bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Cauliflower-like growths on the vaginal wall and vulva are most likely genital warts. Although these are common in the setting of HIV infection, they are often asymptomatic and are infrequently associated with postcoital bleeding.

C) CORRECT:

Irregular bleeding that is exacerbated by sexual intercourse is a typical presentation of cervical cancer. Pelvic examination in patients with cervical cancer typically reveals a lesion at the transformation zone of the cervix, where the cancer is most likely to originate.

The risk for cervical cancer is much higher in people with HIV than in the general population, even in patients taking antiretroviral therapy. One reason may be that people with HIV are more likely to acquire human papillomavirus infection and less likely to clear it. Fortunately, screening for cervical cancer with regular Pap smears is highly effective in those with HIV, just as it is in those without HIV. Thus, annual Pap smears are recommended in this population. Consequently, cervical cancer is a very rare cause of HIV-related morbidity and mortality, except in patients who are not screened according to guidelines.

Key learning point: The risk for cervical cancer is much higher in people with HIV than in the general population, even in patients taking antiretroviral therapy

D) INCORRECT:

Small cysts along the outer edge of the cervix are most likely Nabothian cysts, which are benign. They rarely cause excess vaginal bleeding and are not associated with HIV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Bleeding from the cervical os and the presence of an adnexal mass are characteristics of endometrial cancer and ovarian cancer, respectively. The risk for these cancers may be only slightly increased in people with HIV. Endometrial and ovarian cancers are not typically associated with postcoital bleeding.
questions.hint: People with HIV have a higher risk of developing this condition compared to the general population.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nulliparous woman with polycystic ovary syndrome comes to the office for a pelvic examination and cervical cancer screening. Menarche occurred at the age of 10 years. She became sexually active at the age of 14 years. Her mother had breast cancer at the age of 51 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. HPV testing is positive. Cytology shows high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. Colposcopy with biopsy shows cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade II. Which of the following is this patient's strongest predisposing factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

HPV serotypes 16 and 18 are oncogenic viruses that increase the risk of CIN by producing the oncogenic proteins E6 and E7. The strongest predisposing factors for HPV infection are the early onset of sexual activity and multiple sexual partners. Women who engage in sexual activity before the age of 18 years are at twice the risk of cervical cancer compared to women who are 21 years or older when they first have intercourse. The risk of cervical cancer in women who have had ≥ 6 sexual partners is increased threefold compared with one partner. Other HPV-related risk factors include high-risk sexual behavior, a history of STIs, a history of immunosuppression, and intrauterine exposure to diethylstilbestrol. Higher rates of cervical cancer have also been observed in women of low socioeconomic status and smokers (for squamous cell cancer types only).
Image Description:

Almost all cases of cervical cancer are caused by an infection of the transformation zone (rectangular box) with high-risk types of human papillomavirus (HPV).

HPVs infect the stem cells of the basal cell epithelium. Cell proliferation and migration of virus-infected daughter cells into the suprabasal cell layer allow the infection to spread. At the beginning of the process, the DNA of the virus is episomal. As the disease progresses, the DNA is integrated into the cervical epithelium's DNA. A noninvasive precursor lesion, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), may develop from an HPV infection over months to years, which may ultimately progress to invasive carcinoma.

In most cases, complete recovery will occur during the early stages of an HPV infection.

B) INCORRECT:

While a family history of gynecological cancers does increase this patient's risk of developing cervical cancer, it is not the strongest predisposing factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome is not an established risk factor for the development of cervical cancer. It is, however, associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer due to the excess circulating estrogen, a direct result of decreased production of sex hormone-binding globulin.

D) INCORRECT:

Early menarche is not a known risk factor for developing cervical cancer, but it is associated with an increased incidence of endometrial cancer due to the increased lifetime exposure to estrogen (similarly to late menopause).

E) INCORRECT:

Nulliparity increases the risk of developing endometrial cancer, not cervical cancer because nulliparous women are not exposed to the significant increase in progesterone that occurs during pregnancy. In contrast, both high parity and early age of first birth (< 20 years old), increase the risk for cervical cancer, although these factors may be mediated by increased exposure to HPV.
questions.hint: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) is strongly associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, especially the high-risk HPV types 16 and 18.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine pelvic examination. She feels well. Menses occur at 30-day intervals and last 7 days. Her last menstrual period was 6 days ago. Her last Pap smear was 13 months ago and there is no history of abnormal findings. She is sexually active with three male partners and uses condoms consistently. She has never been tested for sexually transmitted infections. Her 54-year-old mother has breast cancer. She did not receive a human papillomavirus vaccine. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis testing, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

As part of the routine immunization schedule, the CDC states that two doses of the nine-valent human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine should be administered six months apart to all individuals aged 9–14 years. For all unvaccinated female individuals aged 15–26 years, the CDC recommends vaccination with three doses of the nine-valent HPV vaccine at 0, 2, and 6 months. The HPV vaccine is approved by the FDA for individuals up to the age of 45 years, but it is not routinely recommended by the CDC for individuals aged > 26 years.

Condoms lower the risk of, but do not protect against, HPV infection because HPV can still be transmitted via genital skin-to-skin contact or oral sex.

B) INCORRECT:

For women aged between 21 and 29 years, the USPSTF recommends a Pap smear every three years. Since this patient had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago, another Pap smear is not required for nearly another two years.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common indication for a pregnancy test is recent-onset secondary amenorrhea in a patient of childbearing age. Because her last menstrual period was six days ago, this patient does not have amenorrhea. If this 24-year-old woman had acute lower abdominal pain, a pregnancy test would be indicated to rule out an ectopic pregnancy. However, there is currently no indication for performing a pregnancy test in this asymptomatic patient presenting for a routine pelvic examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Cotesting refers to simultaneous Pap smear and HPV testing. It is the USPSTF's recommended cervical cancer screening of choice for women aged between 30 and 65 years every five years. In this 24-year-old patient, the USPSTF instead recommends a Pap smear every three years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend that women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.

E) INCORRECT:

HPV testing and a simultaneous Pap smear, known as cotesting, is recommended by the USPSTF for cervical cancer screening for patients aged 30–65 years every five years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing alone (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.
questions.hint: This patient's history and age determine the most appropriate recommendation at this time.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with known HIV infection presents with a 1-month history of postcoital spotting and irregular vaginal bleeding. Prior to the onset of her symptoms, menses occurred at regular 28-day intervals. She is sexually active with multiple sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include a combined antiretroviral treatment regimen and an oral contraceptive. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen obtained from the cervix shows atypical columnar epithelial cells with elongated nuclei that have infiltrated beyond the basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of postcoital spotting, irregular vaginal bleeding, HIV infection, and unprotected sex with multiple partners may indicate bacterial cervicitis, which is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhea. However, the atypical columnar epithelial cells seen here indicate a malignant process.

B) CORRECT:

Atypical columnar epithelial cells with elongated nuclei that have infiltrated beyond the basement membrane indicate an invasive cervical adenocarcinoma, which accounts for approx. 20% of all cervical cancer cases. Smoking, immunodeficiency (especially HIV infection), multiple sex partners, and HPV infection are risk factors for cervical adenocarcinoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an endocervical biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Atypical columnar epithelial cells with elongated nuclei are visible (green overlays). There is an abundance of neutrophils (as a sign of inflammation secondary to neoplasia; yellow overlays) within the subepithelial stroma indicating an invasive tumor. Parts of the invasive component can be seen in the center and at the bottom of the image (red overlays).

This appearance is characteristic of endocervical adenocarcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of postcoital spotting and irregular vaginal bleeding may indicate menopause. However, the atypical columnar epithelial cells seen in this patient's biopsy specimen indicate a malignant process.

D) INCORRECT:

Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by sclerosis of the vulvar dermis. Common findings of this condition include dysuria, anal discomfort, and characteristic porcelain-white atrophic patches in the anogenital region. A biopsy of the lesion may reveal epidermal atrophy, hyperkeratosis, dermal fibrosis and sclerosis. This patient's presentation is consistent with a cervial malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a malignancy of the cervix but the biopsy findings show that the basement membrane has been breached because the cancerous cells are situated within the subepithelial stroma. Therefore, this malignancy is not in situ.
questions.hint: The biopsy findings in this patient with postcoital spotting and irregular vaginal bleeding indicate a cervical malignancy.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with postcoital bleeding and a visible lesion on the ectocervix. Pelvic exam reveals a 2-cm exophytic mass. What is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HPV DNA testing identifies high-risk HPV types in screening protocols but does not provide the histopathologic details needed to confirm a diagnosis. In the presence of a visible exophytic cervical lesion, a biopsy is necessary to determine the lesion's nature and rule out invasive malignancy.

B) INCORRECT:

The Papanicolaou test is a screening tool for detecting early cellular abnormalities in asymptomatic women. It is not appropriate for diagnosing an established lesion, such as a visible exophytic mass, because it lacks the specificity and sensitivity needed for overt disease. A biopsy is necessary for a definitive diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

A punch biopsy is essential for obtaining a definitive histopathological diagnosis of a cervical lesion. In a patient with postcoital bleeding and a visible exophytic mass, direct tissue sampling provides critical information about cellular architecture and morphology, distinguishing between benign and malignant processes. This approach is crucial for guiding further staging and management decisions. Screening tests like the Papanicolaou test and HPV DNA testing are not suitable for diagnosing overt lesions, as they are designed for early detection in asymptomatic individuals.

Key learning point: In the presence of a visible cervical mass, a directed biopsy is the most appropriate investigation to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Endocervical curettage is used to sample the endocervical canal when no lesion is visible or when evaluating cytologic abnormalities confined to the canal. In this case, a visible exophytic mass on the ectocervix requires a directed biopsy for accurate histopathological diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents with a four-month history of irregular vaginal bleeding, intermittent pelvic pain, and foul-smelling discharge. She has not undergone cervical cancer screening in many years. Pelvic examination reveals a friable lesion on the ectocervix that bleeds on contact. She has no significant past medical history.
Which of the following is the most definitive diagnostic procedure to confirm malignancy in this patient?

choices.text: Punch biopsy of the visible lesion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HPV DNA testing identifies high-risk HPV types linked to cervical neoplasia but does not confirm malignancy. The presence of viral DNA does not verify malignant transformation. In this scenario, histopathological assessment of the lesion is required for a definitive diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The Pap test is a screening tool for detecting cytologic abnormalities, not for definitive diagnosis. It samples exfoliated cells, which may not capture tissue architecture or invasive features. In patients with symptoms and a visible lesion, histologic evaluation of a tissue specimen is necessary for diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Endocervical curettage (ECC) is useful for sampling the endocervical canal, especially when lesions are not visible. However, in the presence of a visible ectocervical lesion, a targeted biopsy provides a more representative sample. ECC's blind sampling may miss abnormal ectocervical tissue, reducing its diagnostic yield.

D) CORRECT:

A punch biopsy of the visible lesion is the definitive diagnostic procedure for confirming cervical carcinoma. This method allows for direct tissue sampling from the friable lesion, enabling histopathologic evaluation for cellular atypia and stromal invasion. While screening tests like the Pap test or HPV DNA testing are useful for early detection, they do not replace the need for tissue diagnosis. A punch biopsy provides a representative sample directly from the lesion, aligning with guidelines that emphasize tissue confirmation as the gold standard for diagnosing cervical cancer.

Key learning point: In the presence of a visible cervical mass, a cervical biopsy is the most definitive diagnostic procedure to confirm malignancy.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old nulliparous woman presents for evaluation following an abnormal Papanicolaou test. She is otherwise healthy, with no significant medical or surgical history. Colposcopic biopsy reveals carcinoma in situ. Pelvic examination shows only a small transformation zone irregularity, with no obvious invasive lesion. Recent imaging suggests no evidence of spread beyond the cervical epithelium. Laboratory results, including complete blood count and basic metabolic panel, are within normal limits. She expresses a strong desire to preserve fertility and requests a treatment approach that would allow her to maintain the possibility of childbearing (see reports).

Colposcopic biopsy: Carcinoma in situ
Imaging: No evidence of spread beyond the cervical epithelium

Which of the following management options is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laser ablation destroys abnormal cervical tissue but does not provide a specimen for histopathological evaluation. In carcinoma in situ, assessing lesion margins is essential to rule out occult invasive disease. While laser ablation preserves cervical anatomy, it lacks the ability to confirm complete eradication of neoplastic cells, making it less appropriate than excisional procedures.

B) INCORRECT:

Radical trachelectomy is indicated for early invasive cervical cancer with stromal invasion, not for carcinoma in situ, which is confined to the epithelium. Less invasive procedures like cervical conization are preferred for managing carcinoma in situ, as they address the lesion with less morbidity and preserve cervical integrity.

C) CORRECT:

Cold-knife cone biopsy involves excising a cone-shaped section of the cervix, including the transformation zone and lesion, allowing for comprehensive histopathological evaluation. This procedure is crucial for confirming negative margins and ruling out occult invasive disease in carcinoma in situ. It preserves cervical integrity, making it suitable for patients desiring future fertility. Cold-knife conization is preferred over ablative techniques when margin status and full tissue evaluation are necessary for managing high-grade cervical lesions.

Key learning point: For women with cervical carcinoma in situ who wish to preserve fertility, a cold knife cone biopsy is the preferred management option as it allows for complete excision and histological examination of the lesion.
Image Description:

Excision of dysplastic cervical tissue including the entire transformation zone

Left: In premenopausal women, most of the transformation zone is located in the ectocervix (the visible portion of the cervix), with only a small portion extending into the endocervix. Therefore only a small, flat cone of tissue needs to be removed.

Right: In postmenopausal women, the transformation zone extends much deeper into the endocervix, with only a small portion located in the ectocervix. Therefore, a deeper cone must be excised to remove the entire transformation zone.

D) INCORRECT:

Radical hysterectomy involves removing the uterus, cervix, and surrounding structures, and is reserved for invasive cervical cancer. In carcinoma in situ, which is confined to the epithelium, this procedure is unnecessarily aggressive and would permanently compromise fertility without additional oncologic benefit.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with a six-month history of intermittent spotting and mild pelvic pain. She reports no Pap smear in the past seven years. On speculum examination, a 2-cm friable mass is noted on the anterior lip of the cervix, which bleeds on contact. Pelvic ultrasound shows no obvious uterine pathology. The remainder of the pelvic exam is normal. Laboratory tests, including HIV screening, are pending (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: No obvious uterine pathology
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis of this mass?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial sampling evaluates abnormal uterine bleeding related to endometrial pathology, such as hyperplasia or carcinoma. This patient has a friable cervical mass, indicating a localized cervical lesion. Imaging shows no uterine abnormalities, making endometrial sampling inappropriate for diagnosing the cervical mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Pap smear and HPV testing are routine screening tools for cervical cancer but are not suitable for diagnosing a gross cervical lesion. The visible, friable, and bleeding mass on the cervix suggests significant pathology. Pap smears may miss invasive characteristics, and HPV testing does not determine histology. A tissue diagnosis via biopsy is necessary for cellular detail and tissue architecture.

C) INCORRECT:

Cold knife conization is an invasive procedure reserved for cases with inconclusive biopsy results or unsatisfactory colposcopy. It carries risks like bleeding and cervical stenosis. For a visible cervical mass, colposcopic evaluation with directed biopsies is preferred for initial diagnosis. Conization is not the immediate step when a lesion can be sampled less invasively.

D) CORRECT:

A punch biopsy is the most appropriate step for diagnosing a visible cervical lesion, such as the friable, bleeding mass observed in this patient. The history of postcoital bleeding and the physical findings raise suspicion for cervical pathology, including invasive carcinoma. A punch biopsy provides histological evaluation, distinguishing between invasive malignancy and preinvasive lesions, which is crucial for guiding management. Advanced diagnostic procedures are necessary over screening tests like Pap smear and HPV testing, which are not designed to evaluate established lesions.

Key learning point: In the presence of a cervical mass, a punch biopsy is the most appropriate next step to obtain a tissue diagnosis and confirm malignancy.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with intermittent bright red spotting during sexual intercourse for the past two months. She denies pelvic pain or abnormal discharge. Her menstrual cycles are regular, and she has no significant medical history. Speculum examination shows no visible lesion, but blood is noted on the cervix. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial sampling assesses the uterine lining, indicated for abnormal uterine bleeding in older women or those with risk factors. The young patient with regular cycles and postcoital bleeding suggests cervical, not endometrial, pathology. Blood on the cervix points to a cervical source, making endometrial sampling unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound evaluates uterine, adnexal, and endometrial pathology, especially with pelvic pain or abnormal bleeding. The patient's postcoital bleeding without pelvic pain or irregular menses suggests cervical pathology, not uterine or adnexal lesions. A transvaginal ultrasound is not optimal for assessing cervical abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's postcoital bleeding and blood on the cervix, despite no visible lesion, suggest cervical cytologic abnormalities, often linked to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. A Pap test is the initial evaluation for sexually active women aged 21–65 years to screen for cervical dysplasia. It detects cellular changes even without gross lesions, aiding in early diagnosis and management of potential precancerous conditions. This cytological evaluation is a high-yield, minimally invasive assessment for patients with such bleeding patterns.

Key learning point: Post-coital bleeding should be initially evaluated with a Pap smear to rule out cervical pathology, including cervical cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy is considered for suspected cervicitis, characterized by cervical inflammation, mucopurulent discharge, or pelvic pain. The patient lacks these signs, with only blood on the cervix and no visible lesions, indicating a noninfectious cause. Antibiotics are not appropriate without clinical features of cervicitis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 49-year-old woman in your clinic for routine health maintenance and cervical cancer screening. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago and was normal. She has a 32-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. She does not take any medications except for a multivitamin supplement. On examination, there are no breast masses. The external genitalia, vagina, and cervix are normal. The uterus and adnexa are normal on palpation. HPV testing is positive. Cytology reveals squamous cells with moderate to severe dysplasia and several koilocytes. Colposcopy with biopsy shows moderate epithelial dysplasia involving half of the basal epithelium with an intact basement membrane. Without treatment, which one of the following is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Superior vena cava syndrome (SVC syndrome) is caused by the obstruction of blood flow in the SVC. The most common cause of SVC syndrome is malignancy, with lung cancer and non-Hodgkin lymphoma accounting for almost all the cases. Although the lung is a common site of distant metastasis in cervical cancer, it is not usually associated with SVC syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic polycythemia is a paraneoplastic syndrome caused by the autonomous production of EPO by tumors. Cervical cancer is not commonly associated with paraneoplastic polycythemia. Cancers more commonly associated with this condition include renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, and cerebellar hemangioma.

C) CORRECT:

Postrenal azotemia is caused by obstruction of the urinary tract. Although the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer in the US have been decreasing as a result of Pap smear screening, if it is not detected or left untreated, it can invade adjacent structures, one of which is the bladder wall. The progressive invasion of the bladder wall can lead to the obstruction of the ureters, which causes hydronephrosis. Cervical cancer can also cause hydronephrosis by direct obstruction of the ureters (proximal to the bladder). Hydronephrosis increases the retrograde hydrostatic pressure within tubules. Consequently, bilateral hydronephrosis can lead to a decline in the glomerular filtration rate, ultimately resulting in acute renal failure. Other local complications of invasive cervical cancer include fistula formation and lower extremity edema caused by the compression of veins or lymphatics in the lower pelvis.

Key learning point: Untreated cervical intraepithelial neoplasia can progress to invasive cervical cancer, which may cause postrenal azotemia due to ureteral obstruction and hydronephrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Pericardial effusion is associated with a variety of underlying disorders, one of which is malignancy. Although almost any malignancy can spread to the pericardium, cervical cancer is not commonly associated with pericardial metastasis. The malignant tumors that most commonly metastasize to the pericardium are Hodgkin lymphoma, lung cancer, and breast cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Leptomeningeal metastases are caused by the metastatic infiltration of the meninges by cancer cells from a primary tumor. Cervical cancer is not commonly associated with leptomeningeal metastasis. The malignant tumors that most commonly metastasize to the leptomeninges are breast cancer, lung cancer, and melanoma.
questions.hint: This patient's moderate epithelial dysplasia is consistent with CIN II, which can progress to invasive cervical cancer if left untreated. Anterior invasion of a cervical carcinoma can affect the neighboring structures.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman with no significant medical history comes to your clinic reporting 6 months of postcoital bleeding. She is a current smoker with a 30-pack-year history. Her last Pap test was 10 years ago and showed a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. On pelvic examination today, you find a firm, 2-cm, friable nodule on the cervix. Which one of the following procedures is the most appropriate next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cervical conization and loop electrosurgical excision are used to treat premalignant lesions of the cervix but are not appropriate for the initial evaluation of a mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Cervical conization and loop electrosurgical excision are used to treat premalignant lesions of the cervix but are not appropriate for the initial evaluation of a mass.

C) INCORRECT:

An endometrial biopsy is a diagnostic test for suspected endometrial cancer and is not the best test in this case, where the presentation is suspicious for cervical cancer.

D) CORRECT:

The most appropriate initial diagnostic step in a woman with a visible cervical lesion is a cervical biopsy to evaluate for invasive carcinoma.

Infection with high-risk strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV) can lead to abnormal Pap test results or cervical dysplasia. Additional risk factors for persistent HPV infection and progression of dysplasia include cigarette smoking and an immunocompromised state. If left untreated, cervical dysplasia can progress to invasive carcinoma of the cervix, which can be prevented through early detection of premalignant cells of the cervix. This is the rationale for screening asymptomatic women using routine Pap tests with HPV testing.

In this case, the patient has a visible abnormality on the cervix, and the best test is therefore referral for colposcopy with cervical biopsy. Although obtaining a Pap test at the time of the pelvic examination would be reasonable, it would not be sufficient to fully evaluate the lesion, and a biopsy is therefore still required.

Key learning point: Diagnosis of cervical cancer is confirmed by biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Staging laparoscopy is not indicated in this case, given that a cancer diagnosis has not yet been confirmed.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman with HIV comes to your clinic for follow-up. She has been on combination antiretroviral therapy since her HIV diagnosis one year ago, and her HIV viral load is undetectable. She has not had a Pap test since her early 20s. Over the past 3 months, she has had progressively worsening vaginal bleeding between menstrual periods, which is particularly worse after sexual intercourse. Which one of the following findings is most likely to be noted on pelvic examination?

choices.text: An ulcerated lesion arising from the transformation zone of the cervix.
A small cyst along the outer edge of the cervix.
A cluster of small papules with a cauliflower appearance on the vaginal wall and vulva.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Irregular bleeding that is exacerbated by sexual intercourse is a typical presentation of cervical cancer. Pelvic examination in patients with cervical cancer typically reveals a lesion at the transformation zone of the cervix, where the cancer is most likely to originate.

The risk for cervical cancer is much higher in people with HIV than in the general population, even in patients taking antiretroviral therapy. One reason may be that people with HIV are more likely to acquire human papillomavirus infection and less likely to clear it. Fortunately, screening for cervical cancer with regular Pap smears is highly effective in those with HIV, just as it is in those without HIV. Thus, annual Pap smears are recommended in this population. Consequently, cervical cancer is a very rare cause of HIV-related morbidity and mortality, except in patients who are not screened according to guidelines.

Key learning point: The risk for cervical cancer is much higher in people with HIV than in the general population, even in patients taking antiretroviral therapy

B) INCORRECT:

Small cysts along the outer edge of the cervix are most likely Nabothian cysts, which are benign. They rarely cause excess vaginal bleeding and are not associated with HIV infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Bleeding from the cervical os and the presence of an adnexal mass are characteristics of endometrial cancer and ovarian cancer, respectively. The risk for these cancers may be only slightly increased in people with HIV. Endometrial and ovarian cancers are not typically associated with postcoital bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Cauliflower-like growths on the vaginal wall and vulva are most likely genital warts. Although these are common in the setting of HIV infection, they are often asymptomatic and are infrequently associated with postcoital bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Bleeding from the cervical os and the presence of an adnexal mass are characteristics of endometrial cancer and ovarian cancer, respectively. The risk for these cancers may be only slightly increased in people with HIV. Endometrial and ovarian cancers are not typically associated with postcoital bleeding.
questions.hint: People with HIV have a higher risk of developing this condition compared to the general population.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nulliparous woman with polycystic ovary syndrome comes to your clinic for a pelvic examination and cervical cancer screening. She had menarche at age 10 and became sexually active at age 14. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 51. She is 165 cm tall and weighs 79 kg; BMI is 29. HPV testing is positive. Cytology shows high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. Colposcopy with biopsy confirms cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade II. Which one of the following is this patient's strongest predisposing factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nulliparity increases the risk of developing endometrial cancer, not cervical cancer because nulliparous women are not exposed to the significant increase in progesterone that occurs during pregnancy. In contrast, both high parity and early age of first birth (< 20 years old), increase the risk for cervical cancer, although these factors may be mediated by increased exposure to HPV.

B) CORRECT:

HPV serotypes 16 and 18 are oncogenic viruses that increase the risk of CIN by producing the oncogenic proteins E6 and E7. The strongest predisposing factors for HPV infection are the early onset of sexual activity and multiple sexual partners. Women who engage in sexual activity before the age of 18 years are at twice the risk of cervical cancer compared to women who are 21 years or older when they first have intercourse. The risk of cervical cancer in women who have had ≥ 6 sexual partners is increased threefold compared with one partner. Other HPV-related risk factors include high-risk sexual behavior, a history of STIs, a history of immunosuppression, and intrauterine exposure to diethylstilbestrol. Higher rates of cervical cancer have also been observed in women of low socioeconomic status and smokers (for squamous cell cancer types only).

Key learning point: Early onset of sexual activity is a major risk factor for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia due to increased exposure to oncogenic human papillomavirus (HPV).
Image Description:

Almost all cases of cervical cancer are caused by an infection of the transformation zone (rectangular box) with high-risk types of human papillomavirus (HPV).

HPVs infect the stem cells of the basal cell epithelium. Cell proliferation and migration of virus-infected daughter cells into the suprabasal cell layer allow the infection to spread. At the beginning of the process, the DNA of the virus is episomal. As the disease progresses, the DNA is integrated into the cervical epithelium's DNA. A noninvasive precursor lesion, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), may develop from an HPV infection over months to years, which may ultimately progress to invasive carcinoma.

In most cases, complete recovery will occur during the early stages of an HPV infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome is not an established risk factor for the development of cervical cancer. It is, however, associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer due to the excess circulating estrogen, a direct result of decreased production of sex hormone-binding globulin.

D) INCORRECT:

Early menarche is not a known risk factor for developing cervical cancer, but it is associated with an increased incidence of endometrial cancer due to the increased lifetime exposure to estrogen (similarly to late menopause).

E) INCORRECT:

While a family history of gynecological cancers does increase this patient's risk of developing cervical cancer, it is not the strongest predisposing factor.
questions.hint: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) is strongly associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, especially the high-risk HPV types 16 and 18.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with known HIV infection comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of postcoital spotting and irregular vaginal bleeding. Before these symptoms began, her menses were regular every 28 days. She is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include a combined antiretroviral regimen and an oral contraceptive. A photomicrograph of a cervical biopsy shows atypical columnar epithelial cells with elongated nuclei infiltrating beyond the basement membrane. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of postcoital spotting, irregular vaginal bleeding, HIV infection, and unprotected sex with multiple partners may indicate bacterial cervicitis, which is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhea. However, the atypical columnar epithelial cells seen here indicate a malignant process.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of postcoital spotting and irregular vaginal bleeding may indicate menopause. However, the atypical columnar epithelial cells seen in this patient's biopsy specimen indicate a malignant process.

C) INCORRECT:

Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by sclerosis of the vulvar dermis. Common findings of this condition include dysuria, anal discomfort, and characteristic porcelain-white atrophic patches in the anogenital region. A biopsy of the lesion may reveal epidermal atrophy, hyperkeratosis, dermal fibrosis and sclerosis. This patient's presentation is consistent with a cervial malignancy.

D) CORRECT:

Atypical columnar epithelial cells with elongated nuclei that have infiltrated beyond the basement membrane indicate an invasive cervical adenocarcinoma, which accounts for approx. 20% of all cervical cancer cases. Smoking, immunodeficiency (especially HIV infection), multiple sex partners, and HPV infection are risk factors for cervical adenocarcinoma.

Key learning point: Invasive cervical adenocarcinoma is characterized by atypical columnar epithelial cells with elongated nuclei infiltrating beyond the basement membrane, often associated with risk factors like immunodeficiency, multiple sexual partners, and HPV infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an endocervical biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Atypical columnar epithelial cells with elongated nuclei are visible (green overlays). There is an abundance of neutrophils (as a sign of inflammation secondary to neoplasia; yellow overlays) within the subepithelial stroma indicating an invasive tumor. Parts of the invasive component can be seen in the center and at the bottom of the image (red overlays).

This appearance is characteristic of endocervical adenocarcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a malignancy of the cervix but the biopsy findings show that the basement membrane has been breached because the cancerous cells are situated within the subepithelial stroma. Therefore, this malignancy is not in situ.
questions.hint: The biopsy findings in this patient with postcoital spotting and irregular vaginal bleeding indicate a cervical malignancy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of intermenstrual bleeding and increasing vaginal discharge with an unpleasant odor. Her last PAP smear was 8 years ago. On pelvic examination, the cervix appears friable with an irregular, ulcerated surface. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial cancer typically manifests with abnormal uterine bleeding, including intermenstrual bleeding, but pelvic examination is often normal in localized disease. A friable cervix with an irregular, ulcerated surface is not a feature of endometrial cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Cervical polyps appear as distinct hyperplastic lesions on speculum examination and cause vaginal bleeding. They typically do not manifest with an irregular, ulcerated surface.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervicitis typically causes discharge and may result in friable tissue, but the presence of an irregular, ulcerated cervical surface suggests malignancy rather than simple inflammatory cervicitis. Another diagnosis is more likely to cause the physical findings and duration of symptoms in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – The combination of intermenstrual bleeding, malodorous discharge, and a friable cervix with an irregular, ulcerated surface is characteristic of invasive cervical cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Nabothian cysts appear as smooth, round, cyst-like structures on the cervix. These are normal findings, and they do not cause ulceration, irregular surfaces, or the clinical features described in this scenario.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman presents with three weeks of intermittent bleeding after intercourse. She reports a prior history of genital warts and inconsistent use of barrier methods. She denies abdominal pain or fever. On pelvic examination, a friable lesion is noted on the ectocervix with slight contact bleeding, but no obvious external lesions.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cervicitis presents with diffuse cervical inflammation, often due to infections like Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and may include mucopurulent discharge. The presence of a distinct, friable lesion suggests localized pathology rather than generalized inflammation. The absence of systemic symptoms and significant discharge further detracts from cervicitis.

B) CORRECT:

Cervical cancer manifests with postcoital bleeding and a friable ectocervical lesion, indicative of neoplastic growth in the cervical epithelium. The patient's history of genital warts suggests prior human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, a key factor in cervical cancer development. High-risk HPV strains produce oncoproteins E6 and E7, disrupting tumor suppressor pathways and leading to dysplasia and malignancy. The friable lesion's easy bleeding reflects abnormal vascular proliferation in malignant tissue, linking HPV infection to cervical cancer pathogenesis.

Key learning point: Postcoital bleeding in a patient with a history of genital warts suggests a cervical source, potentially related to HPV-associated cervical dysplasia or cervical cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometrial hyperplasia involves uterine lining thickening due to unopposed estrogen, often seen in obesity or polycystic ovarian syndrome. It presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, not a localized cervical lesion. The patient's friable ectocervical lesion and history of genital warts suggest cervical, not endometrial, pathology.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical polyps are benign overgrowths of endocervical tissue that can cause postcoital bleeding due to friability. However, the patient's history of genital warts and inconsistent barrier use suggests risk for HPV-related neoplastic processes. Polyps are typically smooth, pedunculated, and less friable than the lesion described.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents to the clinic with 3 months of watery vaginal discharge and intermittent postcoital bleeding. She has never undergone cervical cancer screening. On pelvic examination, a friable 2-cm lesion is noted on the ectocervix that bleeds easily to the touch. No abnormalities are detected on a bimanual examination. She is concerned about malignancy.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to establish a definitive diagnosis?

choices.text: Directed biopsy of the cervical lesion

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A directed biopsy of the cervical lesion is essential for histologic confirmation in a patient with a visible, friable, and bleeding cervical lesion. This procedure provides tissue for microscopic examination, differentiating between invasive carcinoma and other benign or premalignant changes. Screening tests like Pap smear and HPV DNA testing are valuable for detecting early cervical abnormalities in asymptomatic populations but do not provide a definitive diagnosis when a visible lesion is present. Histological evaluation is critical for staging and treatment planning.

Key learning point: In the presence of a visible cervical mass, a directed biopsy is the most appropriate next step to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound assesses uterine and adnexal pathology but does not provide tissue sampling or detailed evaluation of cervical lesions. In cases of suspected cervical malignancy, a biopsy is necessary for histological analysis to confirm neoplastic changes.

C) INCORRECT:

HPV DNA testing identifies high-risk human papillomavirus subtypes but does not confirm a diagnosis of malignancy. While HPV is associated with cervical cancer, many infections are transient. A biopsy is required for histopathological examination to confirm malignancy in the presence of a suspicious lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

A Pap test is a screening tool for cervical cancer in asymptomatic populations. It examines exfoliated cells for atypical features but does not provide tissue architecture information needed to confirm cancer or assess invasion. In the presence of a visible, friable lesion, a biopsy is necessary for definitive diagnosis.
